items.description: GADSDEN, Ala.—The coal ash lagoon at Alabama Power’s Plant Gadsden was supposed to be a model for how to close ash ponds by covering them in place, a process utilities insisted would protect human health and the environment from toxic contaminants in the ash.  Now, groundwater monitoring data and a federal lawsuit are challenging that […]

items.title: EPA Rescinds Finding That Greenhouse Gas Emissions Harm Human Health, Hobbling U.S. Climate Action
items.description: At an automobile dealership in Indianapolis on Tuesday, Environmental Protection Agency administrator Lee Zeldin announced plans to rescind the science-backed 2009 determination that greenhouse gas emissions harm human health and the environment. items.title: As Climate-Related Wastewater Threats Grow, U.S. and Mexico Sign a Deal to End the Tijuana Sewage Crisis
items.description: Every day, the Tijuana River spews millions of gallons of untreated sewage from Mexico into California, much of which ends up in the ocean. items.title: Earth’s Wetlands Are Disappearing and Global Efforts to Save Them Are Unraveling
items.description: VICTORIA FALLS, Zimbabwe—Scientists and civil society are urging delegates from more than 170 countries represented at a summit here to step up ambitions to combat the continued destruction of Earth’s fastest-disappearing ecosystem.  Wetlands underpin all life on Earth, supplying fresh water, oxygen, habitat and food.
